awd_titl_txt: Using Reality-Based Learning Practicum and Mentoring Structures to Enhance STEM Teacher Preparation for High Need Schools
awd_abstract_narration:
With funding from the National Science Foundation's Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship program, "Using Reality-Based Learning Practicum and Mentoring Structures to Enhance STEM Teacher Preparation for High Need Schools" is recruiting undergraduate majors in biology, chemistry, mathematics, and physics and preparing them to become 6-12th grade mathematics or science teachers.  The project will fund 36 scholarships over five years.  In this project, Lewis University is collaborating with Joliet Junior College, the College of DuPage, Midewin National Tallgrass Prairie, Three Rivers Manufacturers Association, Valley View Public School District U365, Joliet District 86, and Oak Lawn District 218. The program will equip candidates to provide the highest quality of mathematics and science instruction to at-risk student populations through rigorous coursework, extensive field experiences, and innovative approaches. Noyce scholars will attend workshops and work with STEM and education faculty as they learn student-centered best practices for the mathematics and science classroom. To further develop their expertise, scholars will participate in community outreach programs. The results of Lewis University's program strategies and accompanying research findings have the potential to address a fundamental challenge facing STEM education today: the success and retention of talented mathematics and science teachers in high-need secondary schools. By researching the impact of the program's emphasis in teacher mentoring and in translating teaching theory into effective practice, Lewis' Noyce program is poised to contribute to advances in the preparation of mathematics and science teachers, help address the shortage of highly qualified STEM teachers in high-need schools, and lead to stronger mathematics and science outcomes among at-risk 6-12th grade students.

Lewis University's Noyce project team will examine three research questions: (1) Does Noyce scholars' participation in a Reality-Based Learning Practicum (RBLP) influence the content and methods of their teaching towards a more student-centered, engaging STEM curriculum, (2) How can mathematics and science teacher preparation programs better define the role of the cooperating teacher, as both a clinical supervisor and a mentor, from the perspective of teacher candidates, and (3) How can programs apply the findings of this research to better prepare practicing teachers? To answer question 1, the researchers will establish a baseline of the candidates' teaching approaches in their first field experience. Following the Reality-Based Learning Practicum RBLP, focus groups will explore scholars' engagement and challenges in creating student-centered lessons, and the researchers will examine lesson plans and observation evaluation from two additional field experiences to determine the impact of the practicum. To address questions 2 and 3, the researchers will utilize (1) entrance and exit interviews from teacher candidates, (2) surveys, (3) evaluation and observation instruments, and (4) debriefing notes by mentor teachers and university supervisors of the teacher candidates. The results of this evaluation will be analyzed to gain an understanding of the impact of RBLP on instructional practice and develop a new model of mentorship that will engage teacher candidates, mentors, and university supervisors in the effective preparation of teacher candidates. The results of the research will be shared with the education and STEM communities via publications, presentations, and the project website.

por.por_cntn:
Lewis University’s Using Reality-Based Learning Practicum and Mentoring Structures to Enhance STEM Teacher Preparation for High Need Schools Robert Noyce Scholarship

The program successfully prepared 27 STEM candidates to work in high-need high schools.  This program and the inclusion of several enhancements to the teacher candidates’ program of study strengthened the overall preparation of teacher candidates and their likelihood of working in high-need schools. 

In addition to the traditional coursework taken by teacher candidates, Noyce scholars completed additional teaching experiences by working as teaching assistants under the direction of one of their STEM faculty advisors. The scholars also completed an additional field experience with a selected mentor teacher from one of several high-need school districts in nearby communities. These opportunities coupled with a summer internship at a regional cultural institution entitled, “Reality Based Learning Practicum,” provided scholars with multiple ways to transfer the knowledge and skills learned in a traditional classroom to the real-world experience of working with diverse learners.  Working in the college and high school classroom, scholars interacted with the continuum of students taking courses to complete a requirement to those who were highly engaged in the content.  The scholars used the inquiry-based approaches learned in their education courses to support learning for individuals, small groups, and the whole class.  During the “Reality-Based Practicum,” scholars shared their knowledge and communication skills with the public. Scholars spoke about the value of this experience in helping them identify ways to draw connections and relevancy between STEM content and the world in which students live.  Several also discussed how the practicum increased their confidence in adjusting to the different levels of knowledge they encountered. While the pandemic significantly altered the ability to complete a summer internship, this program resulted in on-going relationships with Lewis University and regional entities such as FermiLab that will be sustained.

The Robert Noyce Scholarship program sponsored many professional development activities.  Each semester, scholars as well as their mentors and in-service teachers in the community were invited to attend an array of offerings.  Professional development opportunities included pedagogical practices such as coding and P.O.G.I.L. (Process Oriented Guided Inquiry Learning) to content-specific seminars like Sustainability in STEM.  Scholars presented research conducted as part of the Robert Noyce program at several professional conferences including the Noyce Annual Summit, American Association of Physics Teachers National Conference, National Science Teachers Association, and the Mathematical Association of America.  Education and STEM faculty collaborated on research projects including a poster session at the American Association of Colleges and Universities, “Using Reality-Based Learning Practicum to Enhance STEM Teacher Preparation for High Need Schools;” “Defining High-Quality Mentoring: Perspectives from Noyce STEM Teacher Candidates and Their Mentors,” a paper presentation at the Annual meeting of the Association of Teacher Educators; and a PhysTEC recruiting grant. 

The Using Reality-Based Learning Practicum and Mentoring Structures to Enhance STEM Teacher Preparation for High Need Schools is highly successful in preparing STEM candidates to work in high-need schools.  Data collected over the course of the grant demonstrate teacher scholars prepared in this program exhibited a strong correlation between their stated beliefs about how students learn science and how they were observed in their early teaching.  The classroom observation indicated teacher/scholars enacted lessons in alignment with their expressed beliefs. These observations contradict the majority of published cases indicating that beginning teachers often abandon their beliefs about high-quality teaching once they enter the rigors of the actual classroom. Interviews conducted by the program evaluator noted, “All school-based mentors responded, unequivocally, that the Noyce Scholars were better prepared to teach in year one than other STEM graduates.”  This finding is corroborated by a study, “Evaluating the Efficiency of the Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program Using Scholar and Non-Scholar Student Evaluations,” which concluded that the Robert Noyce Scholarship program produced better-prepared STEM teachers overall as the scholars had higher quantitative scores across most evaluation categories than non-scholars, along with a greater number of notable and positive qualitative comments associated with the given scores.   

In conclusion, the Robert Noyce Using Reality-Based Learning Practicum and Mentoring Structures to Enhance STEM Teacher Preparation for High Need Schools program has been a highly successful model for preparing STEM teacher candidates to work in high-need schools.
